entry.title: Re: No edocument created in ecockpit (SAP Public Cloud)
entry.content:
Hi Janarthan,

I don't have personal experience with this but did some research (Joule for Consultants) and sharing it on - alot seems rooted around the guidance from this blog as a starting point t validate proper setup:
https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/electronic-invoicing-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition/ba-p/13578774

and I would guess you've already browsed the Belguin HELP documentation? https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/fba518519f834ed99011786d831ee504/2f9ab027fadc4a52bd2316d3b7e45223.html

These were the joule recommendations though:

Primary Diagnostic Steps

1. Check eDocument Cockpit Status Since you cannot access tables directly in Public Cloud, use the eDocument Cockpit or Manage Electronic Documents app to check the document processing status. Look for any error messages in both the application log (content issues) and interface log (integration issues) - Tobias' blog: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/electronic-invoicing-in-sap-s-4hana-cloud-public-edition/ba-p/13578774

2. Verify Belgium-Specific Configuration The Belgium eDocument implementation requires multiple configuration steps that must be properly implemented [2]. Key areas to verify include:

  • Scope Item Activation: Ensure scope item 5XU (SAP Document and Reporting Compliance) is activated in your system [1]
  • Feature Activation: Activate Document and Reporting Compliance Features through Central Business Configuration (CBC) or Solution Builder [1]
  • Party ID Type Assignment: Confirm your Belgium company code is properly assigned to the BE:VAT party ID type
  • Business Partner Configuration: Verify the customer's Belgium VAT number is correctly assigned as a party ID type [1]
  • eDocument Type Mapping: Check that your billing document type is properly mapped to the Belgium eDocument type (BE_INV for invoices, BE_CRE for credit memos)

3. Configuration Activities Review Navigate through the following configuration sections [1]:

  • General Settings for eDocument: Review all general eDocument configuration activities
  • Belgium-Specific Configuration: Check country-specific settings for Belgium electronic documents

Common Root Causes in Public Cloud

1. Value Mappings Issues Most eDocument submission errors in Public Cloud relate to missing value mappings [1]. Use the Configure Value Mapping app to verify:

  • Navigate to the Belgium namespace
  • Check all required value mapping tables are properly maintained
  • Note that value mappings are not transported and must be maintained separately in each system [1]

2. Master Data Requirements Verify required master data attributes on :

  • Business Partner: Belgium VAT number properly maintained in identification tab
  • Product Master: Required classification codes for Belgium

3. Integration Setup For Belgium, you typically integrate with SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition or a third-party provider. Verify:

  • Communication arrangements are properly configured
  • Integration flows are active and functioning
  • Service connectivity is established

Troubleshooting Process

  1. Review eDocument Cockpit: Check for any processing errors or status indicators
  2. Validate Configuration: Use the configuration activities to verify all Belgium-specific settings
  3. Check Value Mappings: Ensure all required mappings are maintained for Belgium
  4. Verify Master Data: Confirm VAT numbers and other required data are properly maintained
  5. Test Integration: Verify the connection to your eDocument service provider

If you've reviewed those sources and it's sitll not resolved, I'd recommend a ticket on component FI-LOC-CA-BE

entry.title: Re: ADBC: sending input parameter error
entry.content:
The error occurs because the Calculation View parameter is being passed as a column reference instead of a literal value. input parameters must be supplied via PLACEHOLDER with a quoted literal, for example:

 
(PLACEHOLDER."$$CTRY$$" => '{ p_land1 }')

After correcting the SQL string and quoting the parameter, the view executes without error.

Replace your SQL string v_str = SELECT * FROM.........(PLACEHOLDER."$$CTRY$$" => '{ p_land1 }') .

Debug step will show
(PLACEHOLDER."$$CTRY$$" => 'IN')

entry.title: Don't Wait for SAP: Unlocking MCP Servers in BAS Right Now
entry.content:
The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is currently one of the hottest topics in development, promising to accelerate workflows, especially in the SAP ecosystem. Many IDEs already support MCP servers, offering developers enhanced context and capabilities.

Unfortunately, in SAP Business Application Studio (a.k.a. SAP Build Code), you are currently limited to Joule. This is particularly frustrating given that MCP servers were heavily promoted at SAP TechEd, yet the native environment doesn't fully support them yet. This limitation is especially challenging if you are restricted to using BAS because local development with tools like VS Code is not allowed or possible in your corporate environment

In this blog post, I want to show you how to not only use MCP servers directly within BAS but also explore ways to develop with BAS from the "outside" using hybrid approaches.

What are MCP Servers?

MCP servers provide the LLM client (like Claude, Cursor, or Copilot) with more context about your project and system, helping the developer work more effectively. Fortunately, there are already numerous MCP servers available for SAP.

You can learn more about the available SAP MCP servers in this blog post: SAP Build introduces new MCP Servers to enable age... - SAP Community

What Can You Do Directly in BAS?

SAP Business Application Studio is based on the Open VS Code stack (Code-OSS), which allows us to install extensions from the Open VSX Registry. Even if an extension isn't available there, you can often install the VSIX file directly. Since BAS runs in a small virtual machine, we also have the ability to install CLI tools.

Cline Extension

The first option is using the open-source extension Cline. This is also explained in the SAP Architecture Center on how to use Cline with SAP AI Core and in a TechEd Hands-on Exercise.

This extension gives you a coding agent directly within BAS that can not only answer questions but also modify code. Crucially, Cline supports MCP servers. You can install it easily via the Extensions Marketplace in BAS:

Once the SAP MCP servers are installed globally (e.g., via npm install -g sap-ux/fiori-mcp-server), we can configure them in Cline. Below is my configuration example. The command points to the local node installation. You can find the exact path using the command node -p "process.execPath". To find the location of the MCP server, you can run:

echo "$(npm root -g)/@sap-ux/fiori-mcp-server"

This configuration is saved in the cline_mcp_settings.json file, which you can access via "Configure MCP Server" in Cline's settings.

Here is my MCP config file:

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "ui5-mcp": {
      "disabled": false,
      "timeout": 60,
      "type": "stdio",
      "command": "/home/user/.asdf-inst/installs/nodejs/22.13.1/bin/node",
      "args": [
        "/home/user/.node_modules_global/lib/node_modules/@ui5/mcp-server/bin/ui5mcp.js"
      ]
    },
    "fiori-mcp": {
      "disabled": false,
      "timeout": 60,
      "type": "stdio",
      "command": "/home/user/.asdf-inst/installs/nodejs/22.13.1/bin/node",
      "args": [
        "/home/user/.node_modules_global/lib/node_modules/@sap-ux/fiori-mcp-server/dist/index.js"
      ],
      "autoApprove": [
        "execute_functionality"
      ]
    },
    "cap-mcp": {
      "disabled": false,
      "timeout": 60,
      "type": "stdio",
      "command": "/home/user/.asdf-inst/installs/nodejs/22.13.1/bin/node",
      "args": [
        "/home/user/.node_modules_global/lib/node_modules/@cap-js/mcp-server/index.js"
      ]
    }
  }
}

 

Cline allows you to flexibly use different models, including OpenAI, Anthropic, and SAP AI Core.

In this example, I want to disable the "Initial Load" of a Fiori Elements app. The Fiori Tools MCP Server supports this functionality. Even without explicitly telling the LLM client to use the MCP server, it automatically calls the appropriate tool to perform the action.

This is a great option to get started quickly and use various models and providers. However, in my experience, it can be quite slow compared to other LLM clients, and the overall experience is somewhat limited by being "just" an extension.

Claude Code

Many model providers and LLM clients now offer CLI alternatives. Two notable examples are Claude Code, Cursor CLI, or Gemini CLI. We can install these directly in BAS.

I'll use Claude Code as an example. The installation is straightforward:

curl -fsSL https://claude.ai/install.sh | bash

After installation, you need to authenticate. Once done, you can configure MCP servers. You can activate the tool simply by running claude. Once configured, you can use these MCP servers directly within your BAS terminal.

The configuration can be identical to the one used in Cline:

Here is an example using Claude Code to reactivate the Initial Load. Claude correctly utilizes the Fiori MCP Server to find the right tool and execute the change.

Outside of BAS (Hybrid/Remote)

Fortunately, we have the possibility to "break out" of the browser-based BAS and use a hybrid approach with a local IDE. SAP provides a way to do this via extensions. The documentation for this setup can be found here: Working Remotely with SAP Business Application Studio</a >.

VS Code and GitHub Copilot Chat

This approach enables us to connect a local VS Code instance via SSH to our running BAS instance.

This gives us the best of both worlds: all BAS-exclusive extensions and capabilities, plus everything VS Code offers, including GitHub Copilot Chat and MCP servers.

If you follow the documentation, you will have GitHub Copilot available in your local VS Code, capable of using the integrated MCP servers and the model of your choice. This provides not only direct code editing capabilities but also very smart autocompletion.

Here is an example with GitHub Copilot Chat and MCP Server. In this case, although I explicitly mentioned the MCP server, it seems the tools were not automatically recognized, so the model used the parameter in the manifest.json directly.

 

Cursor

Cursor is a very powerful tool with excellent integration of MCP servers. You can configure and use MCP servers directly in Cursor and use with any model together with BAS.

In theory, any Code-OSS based IDE that supports the necessary extensions can establish this connection. For those not bound to BAS, MCP servers can be configured and used directly in your own IDE, as almost every major IDE supports MCP servers by now.

Conclusion

While SAP Business Application Studio currently has some limitations regarding native MCP integration, there are several powerful workarounds. 

It will be exciting to see what support will be available in BAS in the future.
Will it be Cline, as shown in the TechEd demos, will Joule be upgraded, or will GitHub Copilot be included in BAS as announced in a TechEd session?
After the announcement at the TechEd keynote, I had actually expected a quick solution.

Fortunately, I am not currently tied to BAS, and even if I were, I could fall back on the workarounds.

entry.content:
We want to perform a reorganization, ideally on all tables. However, we could not find a note similar to KBA 1757691 that contains a script to perform a full reorganization of all DB tables. Is it possible for you to provide us with a script to perform reorganization on all tables? Or must it be done one by one?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: It's possible to perform a reorg in all tables at the...
entry.content:
Currently, there is no available script to perform a reorg on all tables in the database at once due to the extensive time the process would require. To ensure the most efficient and effective outcome, the reorg must be executed individually on each table.

We understand that this may require more time and effort, but it is the best approach to maintain the integrity and performance of your database.

entry.title: Re: Preventing Negative Balances in Cost Centers in SAP P...
entry.content:
Hello @AlvaroFernandezMorales 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details

Cost Center Budget, Manage Cost Center Budgets, Budget Availability Control for Cost Centers, Budget Availability Control, Situation Handling, Availability Control Settings

Have a look at this Blog: How SAP Solutions Enable Stronger Controls and Compliance for Finance for more insights.

The reason why your Cost center shows negative balances is because the public cloud does not validate balances during the time you post.

You can trigger warning or errors when you enable Budget Availability Control and assign your budget with tolerance profiles. This will ensure the system triggers warning or also block your postings when you exceed the limit you defined. Alternatively, you can also consider using Situation Handling for your alerts.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Changing batch characteristics value using BAPI_OBJCL...
entry.content:
I had the same issue with BAPI_OBJCL_CHANGE which fails with the error C1842, and the transaction code CJ12 permits to save the changes without apparent error.

But in fact, CJ12 actually logs the inconsistency (but doesn't prevent from saving). The inconsistency is shown in CJ12 via a button which becomes active in that case. You may click it to see the inconsistencies. I hope that MSC5N and MSC2N have the same feature to see the inconsistencies.

In my case, the inconsistency was due to a dependency between characteristic values, whose values conflicted. For instance, the value AA of characteristic C1 implies that the characteristic C2 is set to the value 01, but the values AA and 02 are assigned to these two characteristics, 01 is expected, so it conflicts with 02, hence the BAPI error C1842 "Conflict at characteristic C2: old value 00, new value 01", which means that the value 00 is assigned to C2 by the dependency defined in the characteristic C1, which conflicts with the desired value 01.

The problem is to know which characteristics and characteristic values contain these dependencies.

I don't see any tool to trace the problem with detailed information, but CJ12 offers a "list screen" of characteristics with the option to show all dependencies.

I wanted to find a way to know the dependencies by debug, unfortunately I can't find a simple way to explain it.

For now, I'm writing the key function modules, it could help someone who wants to debug. I hope I can find more time to complete the list of internal tables and the exact logic to obtain the dependencies.

BAPI_OBJCL_CHANGE calls the function module CACL_OBJECT_VALIDATION_MAINT which calls 3 important function modules:

  1. CLAP_DDB_UPDATE_CLASSIFICATION:
    1. The current characteristic values are loaded from the database into the memory.
  2. CTMS_DDB_DEL_VALUE
    1. For the characteristics from BAPI_OBJCL_CHANGE which can have only a single value, their values are deleted from the memory.
  3. CTMS_DDB_SET_VALUE
    1. The characteristic values from BAPI_OBJCL_CHANGE are loaded into memory and their dependent characteristic values are calculated (still in memory).
    2. If one characteristic value overwrites a previously calculated value, there's a conflict.

NB: my system is S/4HANA 2023 FPS 1 ON-PREMISE.

entry.content:
Dear everyone,

as part of a S/4HANA transformation (S/4HANA on premise - 02 (10/2024) fps), I am looking to find a way to view stored document history of created balance confirmations in the past per customer/vendor, as it can be viewed in R3 via attachment list function (Transaction VD03 /VK03). I am generating balance confirmations (programm SAPF130D_PDF/SAPF130K_PDF) using transaction F17P/F18P. However, once the confirmations are generated and visible in spool, the PDFs are not centrally stored somewhere and cannot be accessed afterwards. What options do I have for that case or what need to be done in advance? 

Thank you in advance for any advice on this matter

Kind regards

entry.title: How to provision SAP BDC Connect for Databricks?
entry.content:
**Updated December 2025**

Symptom: You want to provision SAP BDC Connect to give access to BDC data and share data products with your existing Databricks environment, but you're not sure how to proceed.

Requirements:

  • Confirm that you are a super admin or cloud admin in SAP for Me. 
  • Make sure you have already provisioned SAP BDC Cockpit.  
  • Provision SAP BDC Connect in the same region that you provisioned SAP BDC Cockpit.
  • Ensure your Databricks environment is in AWS, Azure, or Google.
  • Have a Databricks workspace with enabled Unity Catalog and Delta-Sharing. If you want more guidance, click here.  
  • Guarantee that you are a Databricks admin and have the "CREATE PROVIDER" and "CREATE RECIPIENT" privileges. For more information, click here. 

Resolution: If you want to have a video version of this process, please refer to this blog post from @eduardo_nedel. A great resource! 

1. Open SAP for Me, log in and select "Portfolio & Products".

2. Click "Business Data Cloud" in My Product Packages card.

3. Select "Applications"  tab, then "Start Provisioning" in SAP BDC Connect card. 

4. Type a name to identify the SAP BDC Connect in "Name" (you can edit it later).

5. Select the resource group where you provisioned SAP BDC cockpit in "Path", and click "Next". 

6. Assign the planned Capacity Units (CU) for SAP BDC Connect, then click “Next.” This quota is only a guideline, so you can exceed the usage if needed. If you’re unsure how many CUs to allocate, use the SAP BDC Estimator.

7. Open Databricks environment, log in, and select the workspace you want to work with.

8. In the navigation bar, click "Data Ingestion", then "SAP Business Data Cloud" in Databricks connectors section. 

9. Press "Connection Identifier" to copy the information from system instance identifier.

10. Return to SAP for Me and paste the information from Databricks into "External System Instance Identifier". 

11. Select the region where you provisioned SAP BDC Cockpit, then click "Next".  

12. Review your information and press "Finish". Close the pop-up. 

13. Go to "Resources", wait a few minutes (30 maximum), and you will see a notification message for your SAP BDC Connect. Click on it to check the details, then copy the link provided. 

14. Go back to Databricks environment and click "Connect to SAP BDC". 

15. Paste the URL provided in SAP for Me notification and click "Connect".

16. A green-light pop-up will appear: "Connection to SAP Business Data Cloud was successful. Data can now be shared between SAP Business Data Cloud and Databricks". The process is finished. 

17. Don't forget to create a formation. For more guidance, please check this documentation. 

Image 01

 

Image 02

Image 03

Image 04

Image 05

Image 06 

Image 07

Image 08

Image 09

Image 10

Image 11

Sources:

  • Provisioning SAP Business Data Cloud Connect and Enrolling with Existing Databricks
  • Help Portal: Provisioning SAP Business Data Cloud Connect
  • Databricks: Share data between SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) and Databricks
  • Databricks: Set up Delta Sharing for your account (for providers)

entry.title: Agent Mining in SAP Signavio: Understand agent behavior
entry.content:
AI agents are transforming enterprise operations—autonomously interpreting data, making decisions, and executing tasks ; but as you scale your use of AI, a new challenge emerges: how do you truly understand what your agents are doing, why they act the way they do, and what their return on investment really is?

That’s the value of the agent mining capabilities in SAP Signavio solutions —to bring visibility, accountability, and continuous optimization to the growing ecosystem of AI-driven process transformation.

The Problem: Invisible Autonomy in Enterprise AI

As AI agents become more autonomous, their behavior may become more ambiguous. Their decisions happen in milliseconds, driven by complex reasoning or LLM-based inference that isn’t always visible to end users.

This creates critical business questions:

  •  What specific actions are my agents taking within my processes and how they are impacting them? Are they acting in compliance to my rules and policies?
  • How much does it cost to run them?
  • Are they actually delivering measurable business value?

Without transparency, organizations risk unpredictable outcomes—agents that operate efficiently on paper but unpredictably in practice, potentially introducing errors, inefficiencies, or unnecessary costs.

Discover agent mining in SAP Signavio

Agent mining enables organizations to understand and optimize the behavior of AI agents operating across their business processes. It provides the ability to:

  • Trace agent behavior: See how agents make decisions, navigate process steps, and adapt to different contexts.
  • Analyze impact: Measure the agents’ influence on key metrics like process time, accuracy, and compliance.
  • Monitor cost: Track computational or LLM-related expenses to ensure cost-efficient performance.
  • Benchmark performance: Compare agent iterations to identify areas for refinement.

Agent Mining is available natively for SAP Joule Agents, but it can also extend to third-party or custom-built agents, offering a unique and unified lens across your AI landscape.

The Broader Vision: AI Agent Excellence

Agent mining is one of four pillars of our comprehensive approach to AI agent excellence, ensuring that intelligent agents operate efficiently with the necessary process context while being safely adopted in full compliance and governance.

  1. Agent discovery – Identify the right processes and opportunities where AI agents can drive the greatest impact.
  2. Agent context – Provide agents with the right process knowledge and compliance parameters to act responsibly and efficiently.
  3. Agent mining – Observe and analyze how agents actually behave in operation—what decisions they take, how they perform, and how much they cost.
  4. Agent value impact – Quantify the business value that agents deliver, such as efficiency gains, cost savings, or improved customer experience.

Together, these pillars ensure that organizations not only build AI agents for processes but continuously learn from and improve them to ensure compliance, governance and safe adoption into enterprise organizations.

A Real-World Example: The Accounts Receivable Agent

Consider the SAP’s Accounts Receivable (AR) Agent, which automates parts of the order-to-cash cycle. This agent matches payments to open invoices, interprets remittance advice, sends reminders for overdue accounts, and escalates exceptions for human review. The agent can help produce important benefits, for example, it helps reduce Days Sales Outstanding (DSO) by prioritizing the closure of open items and surfacing high-value follow-up actions. It analyzes behavioral patterns to anticipate risk, recommend next best actions, and support users with meaningful, context-aware insights.

By leveraging the agent mining capabilities in SAP Signavio, the AR team can analyze the agent behaviour and understand why or how those results are achieved, and more specifically:

  • Observe decision patterns: Understand when the agent decides to match invoices automatically versus escalating them.
  • Identify cost drivers: Detect cases where complex remittance language triggers costly LLM inference cycles.
  • Evaluate process impact: Quantify how agent-driven automation reduces days sales outstanding (DSO) or exception-handling time.
  • Optimize agent logic: Spot recurring scenarios that lead to human overrides and refine the agent’s contextual knowledge accordingly.

For example, if the mining data shows that certain customers’ remittance notes consistently confuse the agent, the team can retrain the model or adjust confidence thresholds—cutting costs and improving accuracy.

The Next Chapter: From a Single Agent to a Multi-Agent System

Building on the Accounts Receivable (AR) Agent example, we now take a step further—from understanding one agent’s behavior to analyzing an entire ecosystem of agents working together. In many real-world scenarios, business outcomes aren’t driven by a single autonomous agent but by a network of collaborating agents that coordinate to solve broader, cross-functional challenges.

Let’s now imagine a hypothetical scenario where the Accounts Receivable Agent operates alongside other agents such as one for order management, one for billing, and one supporting customer communication . Together in this example, they form a multi-agent system that manages the complete order-to-cash lifecycle—automatically resolving discrepancies, predicting late payments, and even initiating proactive customer outreach.

By applying multi-agent mining within SAP Signavio, process experts such as process owners, managers and analysts can uncover not just what individual agents do, but how they interact and collectively drive business performance. This enables them to:

  • Discover collaboration dynamics: Analyze how agents exchange information or trigger actions across processes to achieve shared goals.
  • Detect coordination gaps: Identify where hand-offs between agents cause delays, redundancies, or missed insights.
  • Measure systemic impact: Evaluate how agent collaboration influences high-level KPIs such as cash flow, customer satisfaction, or process cycle time.
  • Refine orchestration rules: Optimize the logic that governs when and how agents should intervene or communicate for maximum efficiency.

For example, if mining data reveals that the agent supporting billing often waits for the  agent for accounts receivable to complete validation before sending invoices—creating unnecessary latency—the orchestration can be adjusted to allow parallel execution with confidence thresholds. This evolution—from analyzing a single agent to optimizing a network of agents—demonstrates how agent mining at scale can transform isolated automation into an intelligent, collaborative digital workforce.

In the following demonstration, we show how multi-agent mining in SAP Signavio reveals collaboration patterns between a series of fictious agents.. By analyzing their interactions, we uncover coordination gaps, optimize orchestration, and see how their combined behavior drives end-to-end business performance.

 

Why Agent Mining Matters

Agent mining is more than a monitoring capability— It provides a new level of visibility and measurable insights empowering organizations to:

  • Increase transparency into agent behavior and decision logic.
  • Control operational costs by understanding and optimizing LLM usage.
  • Ensure compliance through auditable decision trails.
  • Continuously improve performance by learning from live agent execution.
  • Measure true business value of AI automation, not just efficiency metrics.

From Discovery to Value

Agent mining is core to maximize the impact of AI agent deployments and attain AI agent excellence. From discovering where to deploy agents, to contextualizing their operations, to measuring their impact, mining provides the visibility needed for responsible, high-performance AI agent adoption.

The result: AI agents that don’t just work—they work transparently, efficiently, and strategically.

With SAP Signavio capabilities for agent mining, organizations can finally see, understand, and optimize the invisible intelligence powering their digital processes.

entry.title: Understanding Validity Periods in Manage Profit Centers: Operations, Limitations and Auto-Adjustment
entry.content:
• Introduction
  • Purpose of Profit Center Validity Periods
  • Types of Validity Periods
  • Core Operations
  • Create
  • Update
  • Delete
  • Limitations
  • Automatic Adjustments
  • Splitting
  • Merging
  • Conclusion

Introduction

A validity period represents the timeframe during which master data is valid and can be used in business transactions. In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, validity periods define when specific master data objects (such as profit centers, cost centers, or activity types) are active and applicable for postings, reporting, and planning.

Purpose of Profit Center Validity Periods

Validity periods help ensure accuracy and integrity of controlling master data by supporting:

  • Organizational changes – maintain structure changes without losing historical records
  • Time accuracy – ensure correct master data applies within the correct timeframe
  • Auditability – provide a complete historical trail for compliance and audits
  • Future planning – schedule structural changes with a future start date

Note: Key components include Valid From (start date), Valid To (end date), and Time-based fields (attributes specific to a validity period)

Types of Validity Periods

  • Active Period – period currently used for postings
  • Future Period – upcoming period planned in advance
  • Historical Period – past configurations retained for reporting and audits

Core Operations

To demonstrate the basic work with validity periods within the Manage Profit Centers app, three simple cases are shown below: Create, Update, and Delete.

Create

Creating a new profit center requires completing mandatory master data fields (Profit Center, Profit Center Name, Valid From / Valid To, Person Responsible, Standard Hierarchy Node and Segment). Once the profit center is created, the system automatically generates its first validity period.

Note: When creating additional validity periods, system rules must be followed (see Limitations)

Example:

  • Valid From: 11/01/2025
  • Valid To: 12/31/2025 

Create Operation

Update

A validity period already exists; however, when dates need to be adjusted (for example, extending the end date), the user can modify these fields directly in edit mode. Extending a period is always allowed if no limitations are violated.

Note: Shortening is restricted when postings exist (see Limitations)

Example:

  • Valid From: 11/01/2025
  • Valid To: 12/31/2025
  • Valid To (New): 12/31/2026

Update Operation

Delete

Although deletion is less commonly used (users are often cautious about removing master data), it is still possible to delete a validity period under strict conditions - primarily the absence of postings.

Note: If postings exist within the fiscal year, deletion is not allowed (see Limitations)

Delete Operation

Limitations

To ensure data consistency, correct reporting, and reliable controlling processes, several rules restrict how validity periods can be created, modified, or deleted. You can edit validity periods for profit centers, but the changes you're allowed to make depend on the following attributes:

Profit Center Attribute

Validity Period Rules

Multiple validity periods

  • Periods can't partially overlap. A period can be lengthened if it doesn't partially overlap another period.
  • Periods must be continuous. There can't be gaps between periods.

Cost center assignment

  • The validity period of a profit center assigned to a cost center must be equal to or longer than the validity period of the cost center.
  • Periods of profit centers assigned to cost centers can't be shortened.
Postings
  • Periods can’t be shortened or deleted if they contain a posting.
  • Periods can’t be shortened if they share a fiscal year with a posting, whether it is within that specific period or not.

Example:

SAP Help Portal - Editing Validity Periods

Automatic Adjustments

To simplify work for users and reduce manual maintenance, the system can automatically adjust validity periods when creating or updating them. These adjustments include:
  • Splitting
  • Merging

Splitting

Splitting occurs when part of an existing validity period becomes part of a new validity period. This happens when you create a new validity period that falls entirely within an existing period but contains different time-based data. If these conditions are met, the system splits the validity periods automatically when you save the new period. Splitting only occurs when two validity periods interact, not three. You cannot create a new validity period that partially overlaps two existing periods. Postings do not affect splitting.

Example:

  • Original Validity Period: 11/01/2025 – 12/31/2026
  • New Validity Period (different time-based fields): 11/01/2025 – 12/31/2025
  • Outcome:
    • Period A: 11/01/2025 – 12/31/2025
    • Period B: 01/01/2026 – 12/31/2026

Steps to achieve Splitting:

Splitting - step 1Splitting - step 2Splitting - step 3Splitting - outcome

Note: The split can occur at the beginning, middle, or end of the original period. Partial overlaps are not allowed. The system automatically creates the resulting periods. More at SAP Help Portal.

Merging

Merging occurs when a new period and an existing period can be combined into a single period. This happens when both periods have identical time-based data and are either directly adjacent or the new period is fully contained within the existing period. If these conditions are met, the system merges the periods automatically when you save the changes. A partial overlap between two periods does not trigger merging. Postings do not affect merging.

Example:

  • Original Validity Period: 11/01/2025 – 12/31/2025
  • New Validity Period (same time-based fields): 01/01/2026 – 12/31/2026
  • Outcome:
    • Merged Period: 11/01/2025 – 12/31/2026

Steps to achieve Merging:

MergingMerging - outcome

Note: Merging works only if the time-dependent fields are identical. Merging applies when periods are adjacent or new is fully contained within the original one. Partial overlaps cannot be merged. More at SAP Help Portal.

Conclusion

Managing validity periods is a core part of maintaining clean, reliable, and audit-ready profit center master data in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. By understanding how periods are created, updated, and controlled (and how the system automatically handles splitting and merging) you can ensure that organizational changes are reflected accurately without disrupting historical reporting or future planning. With these principles in place, profit center maintenance becomes more consistent, predictable, and aligned with both business and compliance needs.

entry.title: 优化SAP Ariba的使用策略
entry.content:
SAP Ariba 是一款功能强大的工具，能够变革你的采购流程，但要真正发挥其最大潜力，必须善用定制化与优化策略。以下是一些实用技巧和最佳实践，帮助你充分利用 SAP Ariba，同时列出需要规避的常见误区：

一、实用技巧与最佳实践

  • 定制用户界面
    根据企业需求定制用户界面，可显著提升易用性。SAP Ariba 允许你个性化仪表盘、报表和工作流。确保界面直观且契合团队日常工作，以提高效率和用户满意度。
  • 利用高级分析功能
    SAP Ariba 具备强大的分析能力。借助这些工具深入了解采购活动，定期查看分析结果以识别趋势、监控绩效，并做出数据驱动的决策。可创建定制化报表，聚焦企业最关注的特定指标。
  • 自动化常规任务
    自动化是 SAP Ariba 的核心优势之一。找出可自动化的重复性任务，如发票处理、订单确认和供应商沟通。自动化不仅节省时间，还能降低人为错误风险。
  • 优化供应商管理
    有效的供应商管理是采购成功的关键。利用 SAP Ariba 的供应商管理功能，维护准确的供应商信息、跟踪绩效并管理风险。定期更新供应商档案，借助平台工具确保合规并降低风险。
  • 与其他系统集成
    将 SAP Ariba 与其他企业资源规划（ERP）系统集成，可简化运营并提高数据一致性。确保与现有系统无缝对接，避免数据孤岛，提升整体效率。这种集成还能促进不同部门间的高效沟通。
  • 持续培训与支持
    为采购团队投入持续培训。SAP Ariba 是动态平台，会定期更新并推出新功能。让团队及时了解并熟练运用最新功能，才能充分发挥工具的作用。此外，提供持续支持，解决团队遇到的问题和疑问。
  • 定制工作流
    根据企业流程定制工作流，可大幅提升效率。SAP Ariba 允许为不同采购活动创建专属工作流。确保这些工作流在速度和准确性上达到最优，并定期审查以找出改进空间。
  • 监控并优化绩效
    利用 SAP Ariba 的分析和报表工具，定期监控采购流程绩效。找出瓶颈和可改进的领域，基于这些洞察实施优化策略，持续提升采购运营水平。
  • 参与 SAP Ariba 社区
    加入 SAP Ariba 社区，及时了解最佳实践、新功能和行业趋势。参与论坛、网络研讨会和培训课程，向其他用户和专家学习。这种互动能带来宝贵见解，帮助你保持领先地位。

二、需规避的常见误区

  • 忽视数据质量
    人工智能和机器学习模型依赖高质量数据。不一致或不完整的数据会导致预测和洞察不准确。确保数据干净、准确且定期更新。
  • 忽视用户培训
    未投入足够培训，会导致用户接受度低，SAP Ariba 无法得到有效使用。持续的培训和支持是帮助团队充分利用平台功能的关键。
  • 不进行定制化
    未根据企业特定需求定制 SAP Ariba，可能导致效率低下。花时间调整界面、工作流和报表，使其匹配企业流程和需求。
  • 低估集成复杂性
    将 SAP Ariba 与其他系统集成可能复杂且耗费资源。需精心规划并分配充足资源，确保无缝集成，避免数据孤岛。
  • 未监控绩效
    定期监控和优化绩效至关重要。忽视这一点会错失改进机会，导致采购流程效率低下。

 

通过实施上述技巧和最佳实践，规避常见误区，你的企业就能充分发挥 SAP Ariba 的功能，提升采购流程的效率、准确性和战略价值。

结论

通过对 SAP Ariba 进行定制化和优化，企业可显著改善采购流程，取得更好成果。运用这些技巧和最佳实践，释放 SAP Ariba 的全部潜力，为企业创造价值。

entry.title: Re: How to set master recipe of process order which does...
entry.content:
In process manufacturing, the machine time for producing a product is often fixed in many scenarios. For example, in the chemical industry, the reaction time in equipment remains consistent regardless of the production quantity. Given this characteristic, we typically configure fixed machine time in the resource master data without considering the production qty.

In the resource (CRC1), you should set this Formula key  in Capacity & Schedule & costing.

An in master recipe, you should use this resource, and only maintain the machine time.

In another word, the calculation Formula  which setting in background configuration, and assign to the resource, then resource used in master recipe.

entry.title: SAP Build Appsでリスト型変数に対しての入力フォームを作る方法
entry.content:
お客様から以下のような質問が有りましたので、SAP Build Appsでのフォームの作り方を解説したいと思います。

"SAP Build AppsからREST APIを使用して外部システムにデータを送信します。JSONの形式でデータを送らなければならないのですが、JSON内に配列が存在し、何個入力されるかわかりません。このような場合入力フォームはどのように作成すればよいでしょうか？"

JSONは以下のような形式でした。（注：改変してあります。お客様問い合わせのままでは有りません）

{
  "UserId": "UserID",
  "Items": [
    {
      "ItemCd": "AA0001",
      "Quantity": 2
    },
    {
      "ItemCd": "BB0002",
      "Quantity": 5
    }
  ]
}

なるほど、仮に注文データとして解釈すると、Itemsのところが購入物のようですね。たしかにこれは毎回何品注文するのかで変わりますね。

このようなパターンに対応したデータ入力画面をSAP Build Appsで作ってみたいと思います。

1. このデータを格納する変数を作成する

まずはこのJSONに相当する形式でデータを格納できる変数を作成します。

リストの中身はオブジェクト型で、オブジェクトのプロパティとしてItemCdとQuantityがあることに注意してください。

また、この変数はオブジェクト型ですのでページを開いたときはNullの状態の部分が存在します。例えばリストであるItemsはnullです。これは後続の処理で少々面倒になりますので空文字列を割り当てて置きたいと思います。
PageのロジックでPage mountedにSet app variableの処理を繋げ

variable1に対し

Itemsに最初から要素を１つ入れておくようにします。

2. ページを設計する

ページのデザインを行います。TREEの部分も名称を変更してみましたので、どこにどのようなコンポーネントを配置しているか確認してください。
Card Container1はカード型のスタイルを適用し、カード型の表示にしてあります。これはItemCdとQuantityはペアで入力される必要があるためですが、どうでしょうか？（デザインセンスに依存する部分です）

3. 変数をバインドする

フィールドに変数をバインドします。

UserId Input FieldのValueにvariable1.UserIdをバインドします。これでUserId Input Fieldへの入力値がvariable1.UserIdへ代入されます。
ポイントとなるのはCard Container1へのバインドです。

Card Container1のRepeat withにvariable1.Itemsをバインドします。variable1.Itemsはリスト型ですのでRepeat withの効果によりCard Container1が繰り返し表示されます。そしてItemCd Input fieldのValueには

Data Item in repeatからcurrent.ItemCdをバインドします。これはリスト型変数の現在行のItemCdを意味します。
同様にQuantity Input fieldのValueにもcurrent.Quantityをバインドします。

4. +アイコンの処理を作成する

+アイコンは機能として「このアイコンがクリックされたらItemCd、Quantityの入力項目の数を増やすという役割をもたせます。前項でRepeat withでリスト型である変数variable1.Itemsをバインドしました。Repeat withの動作はバインドされたリスト型で変数の要素数だけ繰り返すというものです。では入力項目を増やしたい場合は？そうです。配列の要素数を増やせばよいのです。ということで+アイコンをタップしたときの処理としてSet app variableを使用して

variable1.Itemsに対し、Formulaで

WITH_ITEM(appVars.variable1.Items, {"ItemCd": "", "Quantity": 0 })
として、variable1.Itemsに配列要素を１つ追加します。これでRepeat withで繰り返される回数が1回増え、入力フィールドが増えるということになります。Previewで実際の動きを見てみましょう。

+アイコンをタップすると

Itemsの入力フィールドが増えていくのが確認できると思います。

5. -アイコンの処理を作成する

-アイコンは+アイコンとは逆にItemsの入力フィールドを消すということです。つまりはvariable1.Itemsの配列数を減らすということです。ということで-アイコンをタップしたときの処理としてset app variableを使用し、variable1.Itemsに対し

Formulaを使用して

REMOVE_ITEM(appVars.variable1.Items, index==repeatedInfo.current.index)
としてリストから現在行の要素を削除します。
repeatedInfo.current.indexはRepeat with機能を使用したオブジェクトで使用できるシステム変数です。式エディタのRepeat Informationから参照できます。他にも現在行が最初なのか最後なのか、奇数か偶数か、等面白い変数が用意されていますよ。

Previewで動作を確認すると、-アイコンのタップで入力フィールドが消えることを確認できるはずです。

6. フォームへの入力値をJSON形式に直して確認する

入力フォームは出来上がりましたので、あとは目的のJSONになるのかを確認します。ボタンを配置して、このボタンをタップしたときの処理を割り当てます。
ここで重要なポイントがあります。まずはENCODE_JSON関数を使用してvariable1の内容を

そのままAlertダイアログで表示したいと思います。

データを入力してボタンをクリックします。

全文が見えませんので、コピー＆ペーストしてみてみます。

{"Items":[{"ItemCd":"ItemCd1","Quantity":"10"},{"ItemCd":"ItemCd2","Quantity":"20"}],"UserId":"User1"}

これはよく見ていただくと解るのですが、Quantityの後の数値がダブルクォートで囲まれて文字列になっています。
このブログの冒頭にありますように、この部分は数値であることがRESTサービス側で要求されています。
なぜこのようになったのかというと、SAP Build Appsで開発したこのアプリケーションはWebアプリケーションであり、Java Scriptに変換されて動作するためです。Java ScriptとHTMLの仕様として以下のものがあります。

  • JavaScriptは「動的型付け言語」なので、変数自体に型は固定されておらず、あとから数値→文字列→オブジェクトというように中身の型を自由に変えることができます。
  • HTMLの入力フィールドへの入力値（HTMLInputElement.value ）はJavaScript では文字列として扱われます。

ページ上のQuantity Input fieldのValueにはvariable1のQuantityをバインドしましたが、これはHTMLレベルでは入力フィールドへの入力値です。そしてQuantity自体はNumber型を指定していますが、代入が出来てしまうので文字列型のまま代入されるということになります。バインド時にNUMBER関数を使用するという事ができませんので、表示時に数値型に変換するロジックを挟んで見ましょう。

variable1.Itemsに対してのset app variableのロジックです。Assigned valueにはFormulaとして以下を設定しています。

MAP(appVars.variable1.Items, { "ItemCd": item.ItemCd , "Quantity": NUMBER(item.Quantity)})

MAP関数を使用してappVars.variable1.Itemsの内容をitemというリスト型変数で取り出せるようにして、オブジェクト型の変数を再定義し、この際にNUMBER関数でQuantityの値を数値型に変換してappVars.variable1.Itemsに再代入という処理です。
動きを見てみましょう。

{"Items":[{"ItemCd":"ItemCd1","Quantity":10},{"ItemCd":"ItemCd2","Quantity":20}],"UserId":"User1"}

これで要求されるJSONの形式になりました。本当はこのあたりもSAP Build Appsでフォローしてくれると良いのですが。現状はこの様なやり方で対処する必要があります。

Repeat withは配列数分だけ繰り返す処理です。その配列自体の長さの変化にも追随できます。これをうまく利用することで複数項目の入力フィールドを作成することも可能です。実際にあるシチュエーションと思いますので使いこなしてください。

entry.title: What is the Data Retrieval Logic in a Balance Sheet/ Income Statements？
entry.content:
一.What is a Balance Sheet/ Income Statements?
This is a financial statement that outlines a company's financial position at a specific moment. It consists of three main components:

  1. Assets: The resources owned by a business, categorized into current assets (e.g., cash, accounts receivable, inventory) and non-current assets (e.g., buildings, machinery, intangible assets).

  2. Liabilities: The debts and obligations the company must repay, split into current liabilities (e.g., accounts payable, short-term loans) and long-term liabilities (e.g., long-term debt, bonds).

  3. Owner's Equity: Also known as shareholders' equity, it represents the residual interest in the assets of the company after deducting liabilities, typically comprising paid-in capital and retained earnings.

These elements are bound by the fundamental balance sheet equation: Assets = Liabilities + Owner’s Equity.

二.Data Retrieval Logic for "Undistributed Profits"
In the context of executing a period-end report, such as a Chinese balance sheet or profit and loss statement, understanding the data retrieval logic is essential, particularly for items like "Undistributed Profits." Users may often question the accuracy of this item, and verification can be approached systematically by examining the financial statement configuration:

  1. Configuration: "Undistributed Profits" is extracted from the retained earnings account and SAP's standard net profit nodes. Since the calculation nodes automate this process, one cannot drill down to transaction details directly from the balance sheet.

  2. Verification Process: Users should utilize tools such as "Display G/L Account Balances" to examine beginning, ending, and period transaction balances to ensure figures are accurate.

  3. Example Logic for Year-End Reports:
    As an example for executing the Chinese balance sheet/profit and loss statement for the end of 2024 and 2025, the data retrieval logic for the "Undistributed Profits" item is as follows:

    • "Undistributed Profits" balance at the beginning of 2024 = Retained earnings account balance at the beginning of 2024 + Net profit node's beginning balance (generally, after normal year-end closing, the net profit balance has been carried forward, so the beginning balance should be 0).

       

    • "Undistributed Profits" balance at the end of 2024 = Retained earnings account balance at the end of 2024 + Net profit balance for the year.

       

    • "Undistributed Profits" balance at the beginning of 2025 = Retained earnings account balance at the beginning of 2025 + Net profit node's beginning balance (generally, after normal year-end closing, the net profit balance has been carried forward, so the beginning balance should be 0).

       

    • "Undistributed Profits" balance at the end of 2025 = Retained earnings account balance at the end of 2024 + Net profit balance for the current year.

       

    • After proper year-end closing, the beginning balance for the "Undistributed Profits" item in 2025 should equal the ending balance for 2024, which means that the retained earnings account balance at the beginning of 2025 = retained earnings account balance at the end of 2024 + net profit for the 2024 period.

Conclusion

The data retrieval logic in a balance sheet, particularly for "Undistributed Profits," involves a blend of systematic configuration and thorough verification. By meticulously following these processes, companies can ensure the accuracy of their financial disclosures, ultimately aiding in informed decision-making.

Hope the information could help you.

Best regards,

Lola

entry.title: 科目凭证输出的模板自定义
entry.content:
一.“科目凭证输出”app主要是做什么的？
通过此应用，您可以显示不同总账科目的借项和贷项过账，并按照中国法律的要求进行打印。
用户可选择ALV清单，PDF预览、PDF直接打印三种输出类型查看会计凭证，支持总账视图/条目视图的切换，支持会计凭单类型的选择，在Cloud上直接批量打印会计凭证需要设置打印机队列及指定默认的打印表单。
“PDF报表标题”“会计部经理““审批人”支持用户指定凭证打印时显示的抬头和落款人；
“备选科目编号“支持凭证打印时显示备选科目编号；
“批输入的排序字段“支持用户在批量显示会计凭证时，设定按照哪个字段进行排序。例如此处可设置按照按月官方凭证编号进行排序。

二.自定义表单
打开app“维护表单模板”，在过滤器的表单模板名称中输入“IDCN_ACC_DOC_OM”，
点击表单模板“IDCN_ACC_DOC_OM”详情页上的”下载“图标，以下载SAP预设的表单模
板。
将下载的压缩包解压，打开Adobe Live Cycle Designer，并从中打开压缩包中解压出的文件 IDCN_ACC_DOC_OM_E.xdp。
1)如果你想调整预设表单的布局，在原有基础上增加一列字段显示凭证的成本中心:
a.用Adobe live cycle designer打开form IDCN_ACC_DOC_OM_E.xdp，在表单布局中新
增一个字段

b.在Adobe Live Cycle Designer中切换到Data View页签，将Ktosl字段拖入成本中心列
标黄的区域，如下图截屏所示。

2)针对固定资产凭证，你希望固定资产原值和固定资产累计折旧科目在打印时，“明细”栏能显示科目/资产主数据描述，而不是仅仅只显示固定资产编号:
a. 用Adobe live cycle designer打开form IDCN_ACC_DOC_OM_E.xdp，双击要对其进行
添加/修改Script的单元格，打开script编辑器。
本实例就是双击以下高亮为黄色的“明细”栏，上半个窗口中打开的就是Script 编辑器：

b. 修改已经存在的Script 代码，添加黄色高亮部分所标注的代码，目的是当行项目的科目类型是固定资产的时候，我们除了显示科目编号和资产编号之外还同时显示科目的描述(在本例中只修改了以本位币显示并且是非备选科目的Form)

再次打开“维护表单模板“应用，切换到”定制模板“页签下，点击”新建“图标。

在弹出的窗口中输入以下信息：
• 表单模板名称：根据本企业的命名规则维护表单模板名称；
• 语言：如果下载的预设表单模板为英文，则这里选择“英文”，其他情况同理；
• 选择表单模板文件：选择在Adobe Live Cycle Designer中更新过的xdp文件；
• 数据源：选择中国会计凭证打印数据源“FDP_IDCN_ACC_DOC_SRV”。
在下一屏幕，在“可使用国家“字段中选择”中国“。如果后期有翻译成中文版本的模板，你可以
点击”新的翻译“来上传中文版本的定制xdp文档。然后点击“保存”来保存你的定制模板。

希望如上信息可以帮助到您。

Best regards,

Lola

entry.title: Re: displaying .msg attachments
entry.content: If you would like to access .msg files, you can first check the .msg file directly within your Copy & Paste application (e.g., Outlook) via double-clicking it twice; if this doesn't work, there are several websites that offer an ability to view and access .msg files directly from a webpage (also known as "online" viewers) or in your computers native Mail program (e.g., Windows Mail, Mac Mail, etc.). Occasionally there can be an issue with .msg file corruption; in this case you would want to obtain another copy of the .msg file either by downloading it again from the sender or requesting a resend from the original sender. In instances where .msg attachments are still not displaying properly, the best option would be to utilize a proven third-party product. One such provider *** REMOVED BY MODERATION*** which allows users to open, view and convert .msg emails directly into other formats such as PDF, EML, MBOX or PST without requiring Outlook. This software provides efficiency and ease of use and is simple enough to be utilized by non-technical users.

entry.title: Navigate to Custom Service UI from Mashup in SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2 and SAP ESM
entry.content:
In Sales and Service Cloud V2 extensible ecosystem, seamless navigation between standard and custom UIs is vital for enhancing productivity and supporting flexible business processes. Until now, you could easily navigate from a mashup to the UIs (Details, Quick Create, Quick View, Details View) of standard entities—like Case, Account, and others—but not to your own custom Uis created by Admin via Custom Services setting.

Now,  Sales and Service Cloud V2  introduces support to directly navigate from mashups to custom UIs—whether they’re generated by the platform or has mashup embedded. This blog guides you on how to achieve that, and why this is a game changer for side-by-side extensibility.

Why Is This Important?

  • Consistent User Journeys: Allow users to open custom  screens directly from anywhere your mashup is used.
  • Efficient Workflows: For customers, custom navigation means fewer screen switches and better productivity.
  • Flexible Extensibility: Supports advanced side-by-side extensibility scenarios, vital for custom innovation leveraging standard and custom solutions together.

Example Use Case

Imagine you build a "Custom Request Order" object. Your support agent works from an Account screen (standard entity) with a mashup showing quick stats. Now, with this new feature, the agent clicks a link/button in the mashup and jumps directly to the custom Service Request UI.

How To: Enable Navigation to Custom UI from Mashup

Step 1 : Create Custom Service

Create working Custom Service of any type either Mashup Based or Entity Based respectively with required UIViews ( Details, Quick Create, Quick View, Worklist).

After generating the UI, You will notice a Routing Key in Design App UI. This Routing Key uniquely identifies your custom UI in the navigation framework. Since its custom, key starts with “customer.ssc”.

                                       

Tip: The Routing Key is required for navigation and note it down for future use.

Step 2 : Add Navigation Trigger in Mashup Application

With your custom service UI and its Routing Key ready, the next step is to enable users to trigger the navigation from your mashup application.

Since mashups are loaded in an IFrame in SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2, navigation must be communicated to the host application using the “postMessage” mechanism. This ensures secure and reliable cross-frame communication.

Implement postMessage with Navigation Parameters

To enable SAP Sales and Service Cloud V2 to recognize a navigation request from your mashup, send a structured message containing all necessary navigation details and parameters. Object Parameter structure is mentioned below:

PostMessage Parameter Structure

  • Create an object with the following structure:

{

  operation: "navigation",           // Mandatory: Identifies this as a navigation scenario

  params: {                          // Mandatory: Navigation details

    objectKey: "",                   // Mandatory((for Details/Quick View) : UUID of the custom instance

    routingKey: "",                  // Mandatory: Unique key for your UI view

    viewType: ""                     // Mandatory: Type of view to open ("list", "details", "quickcreate", "quickview")

  }

}

Example:

function openCustomRequestOrderDetails() {

  var ReqDetails = {

    operation: "navigation",

    params: {

      objectKey: "067da462-f76e-41c6-9c16-d6ec5c3494e3",   // Example UUID

      routingKey: "customer.ssc.CUSXXXX",                   // Your custom UI routing key

      viewType: "details"                                   // Target UI view: list, details, quickcreate, or quickview

    }

  };

  self.window.parent.postMessage(ReqDetails, '*');

}

Security Note:

    • In production, replace "*" with the actual origin of your SAP application for added security.
    • Ensure that only trusted messages are acted upon in the host application. 
  • Attach this function with Button Click or with any element as required. Example:

<input type='button' value='Open Custom Request' onclick= openCustomRequestOrderDetails ()/>

Step 3 : Create and Integrate Your Mashup in Sales and Service Cloud V2

Create an HTML Mashup

  • As an Administrator, navigate to Mashup Authoring setting  in Sales and Service Cloud.
  • Select Create > HTML Mashup.
  • Provide the Mashup application URL,other mandatory and required data .

                                     

 Add  Mashup in target UI

  • Go to the Adaptation menu in the target UI (for example, Case, Account, etc).
  • Add the mashup as a section or tab using the Adaptation Menu. Place your mashup where it makes the most sense for user workflow.

                                              

Save and Apply the changes.  Its done  🙂

 

Please find the Examples function for List View, Quick Create and Quick View respectively.

 

// Sample function to open Quick Create

function openCustomServiceCreateWithRoutingKey() {
        var oQCObject = {operation: "navigation", params: {routingKey: "customer.ssc.CUSXXXX", viewType: "quickcreate"}};
               self.window.parent.postMessage(oQCObject , '*')
            }
 
// Sample function to open Quick View
    function openCustomServiceQVWithRoutingKey() {
           var oQVObject = {operation: "navigation", params: {objectKey: "067da462-f76e-41c6-9c16-d6ec5c3494e3", routingKey: "customer.ssc.CUSXXXX", viewType: "quickview"}};
          self.window.parent.postMessage(oQVObject , '*')
     }
 
// Sample function to open List View
 function openCustomServiceListWithRoutingKey() {
       var oListObject = { operation: "navigation", params: {routingKey: "customer.ssc.CUSXXXX", viewType: "list"}};
         self.window.parent.postMessage(oListObject , '*')
                        }

Related Help Document:

Custom Services

Mashups

entry.title: How to create an input form for a list-type variable in SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
A customer asked the following question, so I would like to explain how to create a form in SAP Build Apps.

"I want to send data from SAP Build Apps to an external system using a REST API. The data must be sent in JSON format, but there is an array in the JSON, and we don't know how many items will be entered. In such a case, how should the input form be created?"

The JSON had the following structure. (Note: It has been modified and is not exactly the same as the customer’s inquiry.)

 

{
  "UserId": "UserID",
  "Items": [
    {
      "ItemCd": "AA0001",
      "Quantity": 2
    },
    {
      "ItemCd": "BB0002",
      "Quantity": 5
    }
  ]
}

 

I see; if this is interpreted as order data, the Items section seems to represent the purchased products. Indeed, this will vary depending on how many items are ordered each time.

I would like to create a data entry screen in SAP Build Apps that can handle this kind of pattern.

1. Create a variable to store this data.

First, create a variable that can store data in a format corresponding to this JSON.

Note that the contents of the list are objects, and each object has properties ItemCd and Quantity. Also, since this variable is an object type, some parts may be null when the page is first opened. For example, the Items list might be null. This can cause some trouble in later steps.
so I want to assign an empty string instead. In the page logic, connect a Set app variable action to the Page mounted event.

For variable1

I will put one element into Items from the beginning , as initial value.

2. Page Design


I will now design the page. The names of each object have been changed to make them easier to understand, so please check the TREE section in the screenshot to see where and what kind of components are placed.
The "Card Container1" has a card-style layout applied so that it is displayed as a card. This is because ItemCd and Quantity need to be entered as a pair, but what do you think? (This part depends on design sense.)）

3. Bind Variables

Bind variables to input fields.

Bind variable1.UserId to the Value of the "UserId Input Field". This will assign the value entered in the "UserId Input Field" to variable1.UserId. The key point here is how "Card Container1" is bound.

Bind variable1.Items to the "Repeat with" property of "Card Container1". Since variable1.Items is a list type, "Card Container1" will be displayed repeatedly by the effect of Repeat with. Then, for the Value of the "ItemCd Input field",

Bind current.ItemCd from "Data Item in repeat". This refers to the ItemCd of the current row of the list-type variable. Likewise, bind current.Quantity to the Value of the "Quantity Input field".

4. Create logic for plus icon

The plus icon will have the role that when it is clicked, it increases the number of ItemCd and Quantity input fields. In the previous section, I bound the list-type variable variable1.Items to "Repeat with". The behavior of Repeat with is to repeat according to the number of elements in the bound list-type variable. So what should I do if I want to increase the number of input fields? Exactly, I just need to increase the number of elements in the array. Therefore, as the action when the plus  icon is tapped, I use "Set app variable",

For variable1.Items, use Formula

WITH_ITEM(appVars.variable1.Items, {"ItemCd": "", "Quantity": 0 })
Add one array element to variable1.Items with the above settings. This will increase the number of repetitions in "Repeat with" by one and thus increase the number of input fields. Let’s check how it actually works in the Preview.

Tap plus icon ,

you will be able to see increase input fields for items.

5. Create logic for minus icon

The minus icon does the opposite of the plus icon; it removes an Items input field. In other words, it decreases the number of elements in the variable1.Items array. Therefore, as the action when the minus icon is tapped, use "Set app variable" for variable1.Items.

use Formula

REMOVE_ITEM(appVars.variable1.Items, index==repeatedInfo.current.index)
Set the above formula to delete the element in the current row.
"repeatedInfo.current.index" is a system variable that can be used with objects that use the "Repeat with" feature. You can reference it from "Repeat Information" in the formula editor, and there are other interesting variables such as whether the current row is the first or last one, or whether it is odd or even. When you check the behavior in the Preview, you should see that tapping the minus icon removes the input field.

6. Convert the values entered in the form to JSON format and verify them.

The input form is now complete, so the next step is to check whether it becomes the desired JSON. Place a button and assign the processing that will run when this button is tapped.

There is an important point here: first, use the ENCODE_JSON function on the contents of variable1.

I would like to display it as-is in an Alert dialog.

Enter the data in the Preview and click the button.

I can’t see the entire text, so I’ll copy and paste it to check.

{"Items":[{"ItemCd":"ItemCd1","Quantity":"10"},{"ItemCd":"ItemCd2","Quantity":"20"}],"UserId":"User1"}

Looking closely, you can see that the value after Quantity is enclosed in double quotes and is therefore a string. As mentioned at the beginning of this blog, the REST service requires this part to be a numeric value. The reason this happens is that the application developed with SAP Build Apps is a web application that runs after being converted to JavaScript. According to the specifications of JavaScript and HTML, the following behavior applies.

  • Because JavaScript is a “dynamically typed language,” variables do not have a fixed type, and the type of their contents can be freely changed later, for example from number -> string -> object.
  • The value entered into an HTML input field (HTMLInputElement.value) is treated as a string in JavaScript.

The Value of the Quantity Input field on the page is bound to variable1.Quantity, but at the HTML level this is the value entered into the input field. Even though Quantity itself is defined as a Number type, the assignment is allowed, so the value is assigned as a string. Since the NUMBER function cannot be used at bind time, let’s insert logic to convert it to a numeric type when displaying it.

Add a Set app variable logic for variable1.Items. For Assigned value, set the following as a formula.

MAP(appVars.variable1.Items, { "ItemCd": item.ItemCd , "Quantity": NUMBER(item.Quantity)})

This process uses the MAP function to read the contents of appVars.variable1.Items into a list-type variable called item, then redefines the object-type variable and, at that time, converts the value of Quantity to a numeric type with the NUMBER function and assigns it back to appVars.variable1.Items. Let’s see how it works.

{"Items":[{"ItemCd":"ItemCd1","Quantity":10},{"ItemCd":"ItemCd2","Quantity":20}],"UserId":"User1"}

With this, the JSON now has the required format. Ideally, SAP Build Apps would handle this part automatically, but at present it is necessary to deal with it in this way.

"Repeat with" is a process that repeats according to the number of elements in an array, and it can also adapt to changes in the length of that array. By making good use of this, it is possible to create input fields for multiple items. This is a situation that will likely occur in practice, so please make full use of it.

Regards,

entry.title: Re: Business ByDesign - Migration from SAP Intelligent RPA to SAP Build Process Automation
entry.content:
Hi Santhosh,

Kindly find my answers provided inline below,

1. Are there any prerequisites, such as additional BTP subscriptions, required for migration? – Additional BTP subscription not required

2. If yes, do we need to configure the migration tenant URL in any services (BTP or iRPA)? –Not required to configure any tenant URL. Changes will be taken care of automatically.

3. When enabling migration, we notice a warning about dual subscription. Will this result in additional charges post-migration? – No additional charges for dual subscription or post migration.

4. If additional charges apply, could you provide a quote/cost estimation? - NA.

5. If charges are applied, can we disable iRPA after migration?  - chargeable not applicable. It's up to the customer to descope the functionality if it's not required.

6. If iRPA is disabled, will it impact existing automations? – Once migration is completed, everything from IRPA will be copied to BPA, where you can continue to work with BPA as usual.

7. If yes, what steps can be taken to mitigate this impact? – NA.

8. Is enabling the migration tile the only step, or are there additional steps involved? – Yes, currently setting the flag is the only step required from the customer. More information will be provided in the next rollout.

Regards,

Poornima

entry.title: New Product Costing Features for Joint Production in SAP Cloud ERP
entry.content:
Co-authored by @GraceZou and @Li_Sen 

This blog introduces new features in Product Costing for joint production in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

Joint production is a process that yields two or more products (co-products or by-products) simultaneously and is managed through a single production order. The costs are apportioned among the resulting products based on the equivalence numbers specified in order posting rules. 

In Production Accounting,  two new distribution rules have become available since 2502 release:

  • Distribution rule PP5: The system determines the equivalence numbers based on planned delivery quantities of co-products in the order.
  • Distribution rule PP6: The system determines the distribution ratio during settlement based on the actual delivery quantities of co-products in the order.

For the subsequent Actual Costing process after order settlement, the price differences are by default, allocated to co-products based on equivalences in the apportionment structure maintained in material master data. Starting from 2508 release, you can use a Cloud BAdI to modify the logic, for instance, to make the price differences be allocated according to actual delivery quantity of each co-product.

System Walkthrough

Below illustrates the above-mentioned processes with two example production orders, both assigned with rule PP6 (Distribution Based on Actual Delivery Quantity).

Order Type Configuration

Distribution rule PP6 is assigned as the default rule for the relevant order types such as YBM1 in configuration activity Define Order-Type-Dependent Parameters for Production Orders as below:

Order Master Data

Two orders (1003402 and 1003403) for joint production are created. Both orders have the same planned co-product delivery quantities specified in Fast Entry, i.e. 10 KG, 40 KG, and 5 KG for co-products SG2200_MA06, SG9100_MA06, and SG8100_MA06 respectively:

This ratio (10:40:5) is taken into the posting rule as Equivalence Numbers.

Production Execution  

Taking order 1003402 as an example, during the production process, time confirmation and goods issue are made to the order. At this stage, the total incurred cost of 44.86 EUR is distributed to the 3 co-products based on planned quantity ratio (10:40:5) as shown in Actual Cost Debit, which is also aligned with the equivalence numbers in the posting rule for now. 

This distribution among co-products stays unchanged even after partial good receipt (PDLV status in order).

Order Settlement

After full delivery (DLV) or technical completion (TECO) is performed to the order, the system considers the output quantities as fixed (5KG, 5KG, and 5KG for all co-products SG2200_MA06, SG9100_MA06, and SG8100_MA06). According to the rule (PP6) assigned to the order, the system determines the distribution ratio is 1:1:1, hence the distributed cost of 14.95 EUR (1/3 of 44.86 EUR) to each co-product regardless of planned output quantity or equivalences in the order posting rule.

Similarly, the cost distribution among co-products in the second order (1003403) is also based on actual output quantity (10KG, 40KG, 5KG), for example, for co-product SG2200_MA06, 8.31 EUR (=45.72 EUR * 10/(10+40+5)) is distributed.

Difference Allocation Logic in Actual Costing

Now, let's turn to how Actual Costing allocate price differences to co-products.

Unlike Production Accounting, which settles cost on an order basis, Actual Costing allocates price differences on an material basis. Any price differences are aggregated for all production orders in a certain period. For example, these differences include variances between purchase order and material standard price, variances between invoice and purchase order of raw materials, or variances between planned cost rate and actual cost rate of activities.

For joint production, by default, price difference allocation to co-products is based on equivalences maintained in material master data as below (4:3:2):

Allocation Equivalence Numbers in Apportionment Structure in Material Master

 

The ratio is read in the Selection step of Actual Costing run (CKMLCP) while difference allocation takes place in the Settlement step. However, before executing the Selection step, you can implement the BAdI FIN_ACT_COST_SPLIT (Apportionment Structure Adjustment in Actual Costing) to modify the allocation logic.

This is how the BAdI is implemented:

1. In your development system, open app Custom Logic .

2. Search and find BAdI (extension point) FIN_ACT_COST_SPLIT in business context Actual Costing.

Cloud BAdI FIN_ACT_COST_SPLIT in Custom Logic

 

3. Specify your own implementation ID and description.

4. Check the sample code and if necessary, revise it to suit your business needs. The sample code in the BAdI changes the standard logic so that the price difference allocation is based on actual delivery quantity of co-products of all relevant production orders in the period. 

Sample Code in the BAdI

 

 5. Publish the BAdI and transport to test and production systems.

Settlement in Actual Costing

After the BAdI logic is tested and reaches your production system, you can execute Actual Costing run steps (app CKMLCP) from Selection till Post Closing.

After that, let's examine the settlement results in Material Price Analysis (CKM3N). Taking SG2200_MA06 as an example, 15 KG (10KG+5KG) were manufactured with the two example orders (1003402 and 1003403) in period 2025/011. 

The table below explains how the price differences of raw materials (5.33 EUR and -5.00 EUR) and price differences of activities (- 12.46 EUR, 0.09 EUR, and 0.87 EUR) are allocated.

Table: Difference Allocation Calculation

Manufactured Co-Products Delivery Quantity in PeriodPrice Difference Allocation RatioPrice Difference Allocated to Co-product by Raw Material/Activity
SG2200_MA0615 KG15/(15+10+45+2)=15/72
  • Raw Material 1420: 1.11 EUR (=5.33 EUR *15/72)
  • Raw Material 1430: -1.04 EUR (=-5.00 EUR * 15/72)
  • Activity 3 (Setup): -2.60 EUR (=-12.46 EUR * 15/72)
  • Activity 1 (Machine): 0.02 EUR (=0.09 EUR * 15/72)
  • Activity 11 (Personnel): 0.19 EUR (=0.87 EUR * 15/72)
SG8100_MA0610 KG10/(15+10+45+2)=10/72Same as above except using the ratio 10/72.
SG9100_MA0645 KG45/(15+10+45+2)=45/72Same as above except using the ratio 45/72.
SG7100_MA06 (by-product)2 KG2/(15+10+45+2)=2/72Same as above except using the ratio 2/72.

Note:

  • SG7100_MA06 as a by-product appears in the quantity structure. In our case, it also plays a role in the difference allocation because the sample code in the BAdI doesn't exclude it.
  • Quantities of co-products or by-products are shown as negative in quantity structure.

Closing Document Items by Actual Costing

After executing the Post Closing step in CKMLCP, accounting documents are posted.  

  • Document 4700000039: The highlight items (1.11 EUR and -1.04 EUR) are the price differences rolled up to the manufactured product SG2200_MA06 from raw materials RM1420 and RM1430 that were consumed in the production.

Price Differences Rolled up to SG2200_MA06 from Raw Materials

  • Document 4700000041: The highlight items (-2.16 EUR, 0.02 EUR, and 0.19 EUR) are the price differences rolled up to the manufactured product SG2200_MA06 from activities 3, 1, and 11 that were confirmed in the production.

 Price Differences Rolled up to SG2200_MA06 from Production Activities

You can cross check with the screenshot of Material Price Analysis (CKM3N) above to better understand these items.

For more detailed explanation of accounting document items and transaction keys (PRY, BSX, etc.), see Actual Costing in SAP Cloud ERP.

See Also:

  • Product Help Joint Production and Event-Based Cost Distribution (Co- and By-Products))
  • Product Help Apportionment Structure Adjustment in Actual Costing

entry.title: Re: SAP MDK SAM - can't switch users without an Internet...
entry.content:
This is the expected behavior for multi-user mode.  Switching users requires an internet connection.  This is needed to ensure User 1 transactions are processed successfully before switching to User 2.  This also allows the application to download the User specific data for User 2 as part of the OnUserSwitch logic.

There is currently no ability to switch users without the Internet connection.

entry.title: Re: Change status of service contract to "Cancelled "auto...
entry.content:
Hi @Rengaayyappan,

There's no stautus called "cancelled" for service contracts. Cancellation of service contracts means you provide the canceling party, cancellation date, and reason so that the system sets the contract end date to the cancellation date you've defined. It will not update the life cycle status of the service contract. You can read this SAP Help Portal documentation for more details: Overview of Service Contract Statuses.

We do provide you an attribute called "cancellation status" for another purpose, you can read this SAP Help Portal documentation for more details: Cancellation Statuses of Service Contracts.

If you have any further questions, feel free to let me know.

Best regards,

Wei

entry.title: Re: The Detail of Service Contract cannot Display
entry.content: If the detail of a Service Contract isn’t displaying, it’s usually caused by a missing permission, a broken reference, or a UI configuration issue. First, check whether the user has the correct access rights to view contract details—especially roles, field-level security, and object permissions. Next, confirm that the Service Contract record is linked correctly to related objects (like accounts or line items). If the page layout was recently modified, ensure the detail section or component is still included and visible. Finally, clear cache or test in incognito to rule out UI caching issues. These steps typically resolve missing contract detail views.
